source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: Specimens of Zircaloy-2 have been exposed at 240°C (464°F) in various locations in the primary circuit of the Halden Boiling Water Reactor (HBWR)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: corrosion rates increased a hundred times, and was under normal conditions about 0.15 mg/dm² per day for pickled, anodized, and autoclaved material

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: Variations in the flux level from 2×10⁹ to 3×10¹² neutrons/cm²·s (>1 MeV) had little influence on the corrosion rate

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: When uranium was present in the water, the corrosion rate increased for pickled and for autoclaved fuel rods, while hardly any effect was observed with anodized material

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: A deliberate fluoride contamination on the specimens increased the corrosion rate in-pile as well as out-of-pile

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: By anodizing this harmful effect of fluorides could be completely counteracted

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: All specimens of Zircaloy-2 were first pickled in a hydrofluoric-nitric acid mixture

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: Autoclaving was normally carried out for three days in steam at 400°C (752°F) and 50 kp/cm² (4.9 MPa)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: The weight gain was 15 mg/dm²

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: The anodizing was done by using an aqueous electrolyte containing 0.5 percent potassium hydroxide (KOH)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: The weight gain after this process was 6 mg/dm²

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: the acid concentration was adjusted to give an average contamination of ~5 μg fluorine/cm²

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: The vapor contaminated specimens had surface concentrations of 5 to 10 μg fluorine/cm²

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: A pickling procedure will leave 0.3 to 0.5 μg fluorine/cm² on the surface

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: A. Reactor core, fuel pins, 240 ± 2°C, 0.04 ppm Oxygen, 0.01 ppm Deuterium, 3×10¹²-5×10¹² n/cm²·s fast flux

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: B. Reactor core in a fuel assembly, unfuelled tubes, 240 ± 2°C, 0.04 ppm Oxygen, 0.01 ppm Deuterium, ~10¹² n/cm²·s fast flux

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk1
evidence_span: C. Water phase near to tank wall, unfuelled coupons, 240 ±2°C, 0.03 ppm Oxygen, 0.01 ppm Deuterium, 2×10⁹-2×10¹⁰ n/cm²·s fast flux

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: Specimens exposed in Test Position B, at a fast neutron flux of ~1 0 ^ { 1 2 } neutron ( n ) / c m ^ { 2 } · s . , and coupons exposed near the tank wall, Test C, at fast neutron flux down to 2 × 1 0 ^ { 9 } n / c m ^ { 2 } · s , corroded with the same rate; varying between 0.1 to 0 . 2 : m g / d m ^ { 2 } per day

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: The corrosion rate was little affected by surface treatment after long exposures. The data indicate a slightly lower corrosion rate for the anodized specimens

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: The specimens exposed in the steam phase, Test D, were little affected by neutron fluxes up to 1 0 ^ { 9 } n / c m ^ { 2 } · s They are still in the pre-transition region after 900 days

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: The corrosion rate of these specimens was only slightly higher than that for specimens exposed in water without neutrons

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: the total amount of hydrogen and deuterium varying between 5 and 34 percent

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: The effect of surface treatment on the corrosion behavior of fuel rods exposed to uranium-bearing water at 2 4 0 ^ { ∘ } C ( 4 6 4 ^ { ∘ } F )

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: Anodized rods seem to be unaffected, while maximum effect was found for autoclaved material

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: Contaminated 5 to 10 untreated 156 white, spalling

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: Contaminated 5 to 10 anodized 28 black, lusterous

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: Not contaminated 0.3 to 0.5 untreated 42 black, lusterous

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk2
evidence_span: Not contaminated 0.3 to 0.5 anodized 33 black, lusterous

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: reactors, operating at about ${ 2 9 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ EMPY $( 5 5 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ , a tenfold increase is found in the post-transition rate because of irradiation

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: In HBWR at ${ 2 4 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ cYmo $( 4 6 4 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { F } )$ EPY the corrosion rate was increased about a hundred times

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: According to Burns, a flux level of $1 0 ^ { 1 1 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 } { \cdot } \mathrm { s }$ was required to give any significant effect at $2 8 0 ^ { \circ } C \ ( 5 3 6 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: our results are still surprising considering the large effect of the much lower flux, $2 \times 1 0 ^ { 9 } \mathrm { n / c m } ^ { 2 } { \cdot } \mathrm { s }$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: Shepherd has made a tentative calculation of the in-reactor corrosion rate under oxygenated conditions as a function of the temperature, and predicts a rate at $2 4 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ EY $( 4 6 4 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { F } )$ which fits exactly with our observations

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: His data are normalized to a standard fast flux of $3 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 3 } \mathrm { n / c m ^ { 2 } { \cdot } s }

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: the data indicate that saturation has occurred already at a flux level of $2 \times 1 0 ^ { 9 } \mathrm { { n } / \mathrm { { \ell } } }$ $\mathsf { c m } ^ { 2 } { \cdot } \mathsf { s }$ at ${ 2 4 0 ^ { \circ } C }$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: The axial flux variation in the fuel channel was observed to influence the corrosion rate both for fuel rods and specimens, the difference being small $( \sim 1 0$ percent) but significant

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: The ratio between maximum and minimum flux in the channel is about 1.5

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: Neutrons > 1 MeV, Ratio: 2500

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: Neutrons 0.85 MeV-5.5 KeV, Ratio: 50

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: γ-rays, Ratio: 10

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: The ratio of 10 for the γ-flux is sufficiently low to give effects within the scatter of the results and still be responsible for the 10 percent variation in the fuel channel

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: tests in steam with γ irradiation $( 6 \times 1 0 ^ { 6 } \mathrm { R / h } )$ EY did not result in any significant effect on the corrosion rate

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: The irradiation field in the steam phase gave a much lower corrosion rate than that in the water at approximately the same flux, the rate being slightly higher than in water out-of-flux

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: The corrosion rate observed for the out-of-flux specimens agree well with other low-temperature data

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: During the 690-day exposure a series of cracks developed in the oxide films of the autoclaved specimens

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk3
evidence_span: No cracks were observed on the pickled and the anodized specimens

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: Out-of-pile and in-pile corrosion rates in absence of heat flux are nearly unaffected by an autoclaving or anodizing pretreatment

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: All of these rods exhibited a higher corrosion rate than other fuel rods referred to in Fig. 1, the increase in rate being the highest for autoclaved, less for pickled, and very small for anodized rods

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: material exposed in periods with no detectable amounts of uranium in the water still has the same high corrosion rate of $0 . 1 5 \mathrm { m g } / \mathrm { d m } ^ { 2 }$ per day

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: fluoride contaminated Zircaloys develop a white, porous oxide film during exposure in water and steam, leading to a high corrosion rate

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: exposed to steam at $4 0 0 \textdegree$ EPY $( 7 5 2 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } )$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: In flowing water at $2 9 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } \left( 5 5 5 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } \right)$ , however, the poor behavior of the fluoride contaminated Zircaloy shows no sign of improvement after 400 days

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: The same behavior was found for fluoride contaminated material which was autoclaved at $4 0 0 \%$ $( 7 5 2 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { F } )$ prior to the exposure in water at $2 9 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } \left( 5 5 5 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } \right)$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: Anodized parallels in this test behaved as uncontaminated material

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: high oxygen pressures increased the out-of-pile corrosion of pickled specimens in pressurized water at ${ \bf 2 9 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ EY $( 5 5 5 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { F } )$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: The post-transition corrosion rate of Zircaloy in various positions in the HBWR reactor is about $0 . 1 5 ~ \mathrm { m g } / \mathrm { d m } ^ { 2 }$ per day

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: fast flux is as low as $2 \times 1 0 ^ { 9 } \mathrm { n / c m ^ { 2 } \cdot s }$ (> l MeV)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: The corrosion rate in the steam phase at a fast flux of $\sim 1 0 ^ { 9 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 } { \cdot } \mathrm { s }$ was only slightly increased by irradiation

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: uranium depositions on the surface, in cracks in the oxide which had developed only with the autoclaved material

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_042_chunk4
evidence_span: 2 to $5 \mu \mathrm { g }$ uranium/ $\mathrm { \ d } \mathbf { m } ^ { 2 }$
